scenario:
Philip Morris International (PM) is a global nicotine giant with a dividend yield above 4%, a clean balance sheet, and new segments that should help the company grow earnings per share at a double-digit rate for years to come. The company owns many cigarette brands, including Marlboro, and sells them in virtually every country except China and the US. 

Philip Morris International's legacy tobacco profits are expected to be durable and grow in the years to come due to price increases on packs of cigarettes. However, the company is not sitting tight and has spent billions of dollars and made a large acquisition to tackle the new-age nicotine market. It has the leading heat-not-burn device, IQOS, and owns Zyn, the dominant nicotine pouch brand in the US.

The company's smoke-free revenue grew 16.8% year over year last quarter on the back of volume growth from IQOS and Zyn. Smoke-free categories now account for 38% of the company's overall revenue and will become a growing piece of the pie for years to come. 

Philip Morris International's revenue grew 11% year over year last quarter, and once the Zyn shortage ends, this should lead to an acceleration of Zyn's volume growth and the company's topline revenue growth. The combination of Zyn and IQOS volume growth has the potential to drive double-digit revenue and earnings growth for many years into the future.

The company's dividend per share is currently $5.25, which is sustainably funded with its $6.46 in free cash flow per share. Over the coming years, the company's free cash flow per share is expected to climb higher due to growth factors, providing room to raise the dividend per share and increase income from the investment each year.

Philip Morris International is a rock-solid pick during this one-time transition from cigarettes to safer nicotine products, with a starting dividend yield of 4.2% and a dominant position in nicotine pouches and heat-not-burn devices.
